Description: Rim sherd of South Ionian pottery little-master cup; interior: reserved band at top of rim, glazed black below; top of rim glazed; exterior: ivy leaf band with row of added red dots.
Type series: Schlotzhauer little master Ionian Cup type
Curator's comments: Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd and the junction of the rim and body is impossible to determine, the sherd likely belongs with his Little Master Ionian Cups and either his South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9B, which also coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type XI (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) or Ionian Cups Type 9C. This type finds parallels with the shape of Attic Little Master lip cups. Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus, the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. Hayes suggested a Rhodian origin for these types of cups but this is uncertain (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 114). Schlotzhauer points out that the same myrtle pattern is found on Fikellura style pottery from Miletus and thus suggest a South Ionian or more specifically Milesian origin for the cups (Schlotzhauer 2012, 108-9).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.778) (Phase 3)
